Headline: France's Macron says "no-deal" Brexit would be Britain's own making
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron urged Britain on Tuesday to come up with a plan to break the Brexit deadlock before a summit in Brussels next week, or risk slipping automatically towards a disorderly exit from the European Union.

Headline: UK lawmakers will try to force May to seek further Brexit delay
Description: A group of British lawmakers said on Tuesday they would try to pass a law which would force Prime Minister Theresa May to seek a delay to Britain's departure from the European Union and thus prevent a potentially chaotic no-deal exit on April 12.

Headline: Rumours that UK government told it cannot hold new Brexit vote - BBC political editor
Description: There are suggestions that Britain's government has been told it will not be allowed to bring Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal back for a fourth vote, the BBC's political editor said on Tuesday.

Headline: May would go for no-deal Brexit over revoking Article 50 - FT reporter
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May would rather go for a no-deal Brexit than halt the leaving process altogether, she will tell senior ministers on Tuesday, a reporter for the Financial Times said.

Headline: May will set out future steps before next week's EU summit - spokesman

Headline: French finance minister says Britain heading for 'no-deal Brexit'

Headline: Britain won't get transition without Brexit deal - EU's Barnier

Headline: Brexit deadlocked again - Parliament fails to find an alternative

Headline: Factbox - Brexit in numbers: How did parliament vote on Monday?

Headline: May's Brexit deal is where I hope we end up, British minister says

Headline: Growing consensus in UK cabinet to accept customs union - The Sun

Headline: Hammond to tell the cabinet to consider referendum - the Times

Headline: UK can avoid long Brexit delay by passing deal this week - minister

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP voted against each alternative Brexit plan - spokesman

Description: A junior minister in Prime Minister Theresa May's government is said to have collected 200 signatures from Conservative lawmakers for a letter calling for a 'managed' no-deal Brexit, ITV's Political Editor Robert Peston said.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP won't support any alternative Brexit plans in Monday's votes

Headline: Factbox: Brexit multiple choice again: How will UK parliament's indicative votes work?
Description: British lawmakers wrested control of the Brexit process for a second day on Monday in order to try to find a majority for an alternative way forward that could break the parliamentary deadlock over Prime Minister Theresa May's proposed deal.

Headline: Brexit in meltdown - May under pressure to forge softer divorce deal

Headline: Conservative lawmaker: May must promise April 12 Brexit or resign

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet members of her Conservative Party later on Monday, her spokesman told reporters.

Headline: British government to hold five hours of cabinet meetings on Tuesday

Headline: Explainer - Breaking the deadlock over Brexit: Is Britain heading for an election?

Headline: PM wants to bring UK together, May's spokesman says after whip's comments

Headline: Brexit is wrecking Britain's business reputation - Siemens UK head

Headline: EU has been patient over Brexit but patience runs out - Juncker

Headline: PM May would have to look closely at customs union if parliament votes for it - minister
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May would have to look closely at pursuing a customs union with the European Union if parliament votes for it, justice minister David Gauke said on Sunday.

Headline: UK opposition Labour - time may come for another no confidence vote in May's government
Description: The time may come when Britain's opposition Labour Party has to call another vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Theresa May's government, the party's foreign affairs spokeswoman Emily Thornberry said on Sunday.

Description: Advisors to British Prime Minister Theresa May are divided over whether she should call a national election if she fails to win support for her Brexit deal from parliament in the coming week, the Mail on Sunday newspaper said.

Headline: UK minister sees Conservative support for Brexit customs union plan - ITV reporter

Headline: May should quit as prime minister soon - Telegraph

Headline: Northern Irish DUP says United Kingdom trumps Brexit

Headline: UK PM May to press on with talks to secure support for Brexit deal - spokesman

Headline: EU Commission says no-deal Brexit on April 12 "likely"

Headline: Risk of no deal Brexit 'very real' - Dutch PM Rutte

Headline: After "grave" defeat, May says Britain is running out of Brexit options
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that lawmakers' "grave" decision to reject her Brexit deal for a third time meant that parliament was running out of options for how Britain should leave the European Union.

Description: British lawmakers rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's divorce deal with the EU for the third time by 344 to 286 votes.

Headline: May must make way for new leader to take on Brexit - eurosceptic lawmaker
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May must make way for a new leader and acknowledge that her deal to leave the European Union is "finished", pro-Brexit Conservative lawmaker Steve Baker said on Friday.

Headline: EU leaders to meet on Brexit on April 10 - summit chair Tusk

Headline: May urges parliament to back divorce deal, guarantee Brexit

Headline: Passing EU withdrawal deal most important step in Brexit process - Dutch PM
Description: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte said on Friday the British parliament's approval of the European Union withdrawal agreement would significantly increase the chances of an orderly Brexit by May 22.

Headline: Factbox: Conservative MPs who have switched to back May's Brexit deal

Headline: If Brexit deal fails Friday, UK has till April 12 to decide - Barnier

Description: Former Brexit minister Dominic Raab said he would vote for the government's Withdrawal Agreement on Friday to avoid the risk of  Britain having to seek a longer delay to its exit from the European Union.

Headline: DUP's Wilson says party will not support Brexit deal today or in the future
Description: Democratic Unionist Party lawmaker Sammy Wilson said on Friday he, and the rest of his party, would oppose the government's attempt to get approval for its European Union Withdrawal Agreement at a vote later and on future occasions.

Headline: Poland advocates for a long Brexit delay if deal not passed - PM
Description: Warsaw is ready for another Brexit delay if London fails to ratify the stalled withdrawal agreement on Friday, Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki said after talks with the bloc's chief negotiator Michel Barnier.

Headline: UK accord to exit treaty enough for smooth Brexit - EU executive

Headline: DUP opposition to Brexit deal 'still stands' - spokesman

Headline: Irish PM to meet Germany's Merkel, France's Macron on Brexit
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar will visit French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday to take stock of the latest Brexit developments, two days before he welcomes German Chancellor Angela Merkel to Dublin.

Headline: Germany's Merkel to make Brexit visit to Ireland on Thursday
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel will visit Ireland on Thursday for talks with her Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar on Brexit, a German government spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: EU's Barnier: approval of Brexit deal today to secure 22 May exit
Description: Britain would secure a new Brexit date of May 22 if its parliament approves the EU divorce deal on Friday, the bloc's chief negotiator Michel Barnier said on Friday.

Headline: Friday's Brexit vote is last chance to secure exit delay - Attorney General
Description: Britain's Attorney General Geoffrey Cox urged lawmakers to approve the government's EU withdrawal agreement on Friday, saying it was lawmakers' last chance to ensure that Brexit will be delayed until May 22.

Headline: No amendments selected for UK's Brexit debate on Friday - speaker
Description: Britain's parliament will not discuss and vote upon any amendments during Friday's debate on Brexit, Speaker John Bercow said.

Headline: On what was once Brexit day, parliament again votes on PM May's deal
Description: British lawmakers will on Friday debate and vote on Prime Minister Theresa May's Withdrawal Agreement to leave the European Union on May 22, a delay she won with the bloc's leaders last week.

Headline: 'Real fear' in parliament that Brexit will never happen - UK trade minister
Description: There is fear in parliament that Britain may never leave the European Union, trade minister Liam Fox said on Friday, as Prime Minister Theresa May struggles to get her Brexit deal approved by lawmakers.

Headline: Last chance to vote for Brexit as we understand it - UK trade minister
Description: Friday's parliamentary vote on Prime Minister Theresa May's withdrawal agreement is the last chance to vote for Brexit as we understand it, Britain's international trade minister said.

Headline: Voting for UK PM May's Brexit Withdrawal Agreement is 'surrender' - lawmaker Francois
Description: Voting for Prime Minister Theresa May's Withdrawal Agreement on Friday would be a surrender, pro-Brexit Conservative lawmaker Mark Francois said on Friday.

Headline: Next UK PM must believe in Brexit - former Conservative leader Duncan Smith
Description: Britain's next prime minister must be someone who believes in Brexit, the former leader of the ruling Conservative Party Iain Duncan Smith said on Friday.

Headline: Softer, later Brexit likely if parliament defeats Withdrawal Agreement - Goldman

Headline: May plans watered-down Brexit vote to secure departure delay

Headline: Softer Brexit now possible, not DUP's priority - deputy leader
Description: The deputy leader of the Northern Irish party propping up Prime Minister Theresa May's government said a Brexit outcome that keeps the United Kingdom more closely aligned to the European Union is now a possibility.

Headline: DUP says it will not back PM May's watered-down Brexit deal on Friday
Description: The Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party will not back Prime Minister Theresa May's withdrawal agreement from the European Union when she brings it for a vote on Friday, the party's deputy leader said.

Headline: TEXT - Brexit motion to be debated in UK parliament on Friday
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's government will ask lawmakers on Friday to vote for a motion approving the Withdrawal Agreement (WA) reached with the EU last November.

Headline: UK lawmakers can secure May 22 Brexit delay by approving divorce deal on Friday - govt
Description: Britain's parliament will be able to secure a delay to Brexit to May 22 by approving the government's Withdrawal Agreement with the European Union in a vote on Friday, the leader of the House of Commons Andrea Leadsom said.

Headline: EU sees no-deal Brexit more likely than ever - diplomats

Headline: Factbox: Who might be Britain's next prime minister if May quits?

Headline: UK parliament speaker approves Friday vote on Brexit Withdrawal Agreement

Headline: Terms of Friday Brexit debate still subject to speaker approval - PM's spokesman
Description: The terms of Friday's parliamentary debate on Brexit remain subject to agreement by the Speaker, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Brexit: DUP leader says abstaining on May's deal 'never an option'
Description: The head of the Northern Irish party that props up British Prime Minister Theresa May's government said on Thursday its 10 members of parliament would vote against her Brexit divorce deal and had never considered abstaining.

Headline: Capturing Theresa May's loneliest moment
Description: Chin raised, eyes front and inscrutable, face exhausted: it was the most telling image of British Prime Minister Theresa May's loneliest moment, departing parliament after her offer to quit.

Headline: Labour will not support a vote on Brexit divorce deal without future relationship
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party will not support Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal if she asks parliament to vote on just the divorce element without the agreement on the future relationship, its Brexit spokesman will say on Thursday.

Headline: DUP not in Brexit talks with UK government, none planned - spokesman
Description: The Northern Irish party propping up British Prime Minister Theresa May has not been in negotiations with her government on Thursday and no further Brexit talks are planned, a spokesman for the party said.

Headline: Brexit debate on Friday will not be 'meaningful vote' on exit deal - PA
Description: A Brexit debate scheduled for Friday will not be a so-called 'Meaningful Vote' on the government's Brexit deal, Press Association reported, citing a source in Prime Minister Theresa May's office.

Headline: Explainer: Last chance - how do the numbers stack up for May's Brexit deal?
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May hopes to bring her twice-defeated Brexit deal back to parliament for another vote. To get it through she will need to win over at least 75 lawmakers.

Headline: DUP not in talks right now with May's government about Brexit deal - BBC political editor
Description: The Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party is not engaged in any further talks with British Prime Minister Theresa May's government on her Brexit deal at the moment, the BBC's political editor said, citing unidentified DUP sources.

Headline: May presses on with bid to get Brexit deal through parliament - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is pressing on with efforts to get her Brexit deal approved by parliament, meeting Conservative colleagues and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, her spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: Boris Johnson says May's Brexit deal is "dead" - Evening Standard newspaper
Description: Boris Johnson, who led the campaign to leave the European Union, said Prime Minister Theresa May's twice-defeated Brexit divorce deal is dead, the Evening Standard newspaper said on Thursday.

Headline: Brexit deal choice is PM's plan or customs union - May's former deputy
Description: British lawmakers who want to exit the European Union with an agreement now have a clear choice - Prime Minister Theresa May's deal or a customs union with the EU, May's former deputy, Damian Green, said on Thursday.

Headline: Rees-Mogg says he hopes DUP will back May's Brexit deal
Description: Jacob Rees-Mogg, a leading Brexiteer in Theresa May's Conservative Party, said he was in favour of the prime minister's Brexit deal and he hoped the Northern Irish DUP that props up the government would come on side.

Headline: France's Loiseau says a people's Brexit vote would be denial of democracy
Description: Britain's departure from the European Union may be mired in turmoil but a second referendum would be anti-democratic, said Nathalie Loiseau, a former French minister now spearheading President Emmanuel Macron's European election campaign.

Headline: UK PM's May's Brexit deal is 'rancid' - Conservative lawmaker Francois
Description: Brexit-supporting Conservative Party lawmaker Mark Francois said on Thursday that Prime Minister Theresa May's European Union divorce deal was "rancid" and that he would vote against it again.

Headline: No-deal Brexit on April 12 is UK's most likely option right now - lawmaker Letwin
Description: A no-deal Brexit on April 12 is the most likely scenario right now for Britain, Conservative Party lawmaker Oliver Letwin said on Thursday.

Headline: Goldman Sachs sticks to Brexit odds after parliament fails to break deadlock
Description: Goldman Sachs kept its odds on different Brexit outcomes unchanged on Thursday after British lawmakers failed to coalesce around a single proposal in indicative votes on the process of leaving the European Union.

Headline: Germany warns of medical products shortage if Brexit chaotic - paper
Description: Germany could face shortages of medical products by mid-April if Britain makes a chaotic withdrawal from the European Union, German business daily Handelsblatt said on Thursday, citing a letter by Health Minister Jens Spahn to the EU Commission.

Headline: Disappointed, says lawmaker who led move for parliament to seize Brexit
Description: The lawmaker who led a move for parliament to vote on Brexit alternatives said on Wednesday he was disappointed lawmakers had failed to find a majority on a way forward to break the impasse over Britain's departure from the European Union.

Headline: Result of parliament votes on Brexit options shows PM May's deal is best -minister
Description: The fact that none of the alternative Brexit options voted on by British lawmakers on Wednesday won the support of a majority shows that Prime Minister Theresa May's deal is the best option, Brexit minister Stephen Barclay said.

Headline: Factbox - Brexit in numbers: How did the British parliament vote on Wednesday?
Description: British lawmakers wrested control of the Brexit process from the government on Wednesday to try to find a majority for an alternative way forward that could break the parliamentary deadlock over Prime Minister Theresa May's proposed deal.

Headline: Angst and apathy outside parliament as lawmakers debate Brexit options
Description: Robert Unbranded stands out from other protesters outside the British parliament, and not just because of his red jumpsuit, wild hair and unusual surname.

Headline: Sterling jumps on report Johnson to back PM May's Brexit deal
Description: Sterling rose on Wednesday on a report that former British foreign minister Boris Johnson, a prominent eurosceptic, will now back Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal after she promised to quit if her agreement passes in parliament.

Headline: DUP says will not support May's Brexit deal
Description: The Northern Irish party which props up Prime Minister Theresa May's government said on Wednesday it would not support her Brexit divorce deal.

Headline: PM May's move falls short for many pro-Brexit Conservative lawmakers - ERG spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's promise to leave office if her deal is passed by parliament has not convinced enough members of a hardline pro-Brexit Conservative group to back her agreement to leave the EU, a spokesman for the group said on Wednesday.

Headline: PM May move shows Brexit talks were just about party management - Labour's Corbyn
Description: Britain's main opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Wednesday Prime Minister Theresa May's offer to step down in exchange for support for her deal showed her Brexit talks were "about party management, not ... the public interest".

Headline: Leadership contest to replace May will begin after May 22 if Brexit deal passes
Description: A leadership contest to replace British Prime Minister Theresa May will begin after May 22 if her deal to leave the European Union is passed by parliament, her office told Conservative MPs on Wednesday.

Headline: Boris Johnson will now back UK PM May's Brexit deal - Times reporter
Description: Boris Johnson, former British foreign minister and prominent eurosceptic, will now back Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal after she promised to quit if it passes, the deputy political editor of The Times said on Wednesday.

Headline: Around 40 lawmakers switch to support PM May's Brexit deal, 40 undecided - Times reporter
Description: Around 40 lawmakers have switched to supporting British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit divorce deal but around 40 are still undecided, The Times' deputy political editor cited a source in the European Research Group (ERG) of lawmakers as saying.

Headline: Brexit: Highly unlikely DUP will back May's deal - UTV
Description: Northern Irish broadcaster UTV on Wednesday reported that the Democratic Unionist Party was very unlikely to give their support to British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal.

Headline: Rees-Mogg says will back May's Brexit deal if DUP abstain
Description: Jacob Rees-Mogg, a leading Brexiteer in Theresa May's Conservative Party, said he would back the prime minister's EU divorce deal if the Northern Irish DUP party that props up the government abstains on the issue.

Headline: May says she will quit if Brexit deal gets passed - lawmaker
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told Conservative Party lawmakers on Wednesday that she would quit if her twice-defeated Brexit deal gets approved by parliament, a member of the parliament at the meeting said.

Headline: May pursuing new vote on her Brexit deal on Friday - lawmaker
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is pursuing a new vote on her Brexit deal on Friday but it will depend on parliament's Speaker allowing it, a Conservative lawmaker said on Wednesday citing the party's chief whip.

Headline: UK government moves to make parliament sit on Friday, mulls Brexit vote - minister
Description: Britain's government will file a motion to allow parliament to sit on Friday as the government considers bringing another vote in parliament on its Brexit divorce deal, Brexit minister Stephen Barclay said on Wednesday.

Headline: Speaker Bercow warns third Brexit vote must be different
Description: The House of Commons speaker John Bercow again warned the government on Wednesday it could not bring forward proposals for a vote in parliament on its Brexit divorce deal unless it was in a fundamentally different form.

Headline: Factbox - Brexit multiple choice: How will UK parliament's indicative votes work?
Description: British lawmakers wrested control of the Brexit process from the government on Wednesday in order to try to find a majority for an alternative way forward that could break the parliamentary deadlock over Prime Minister Theresa May's proposed deal.

Headline: UK's weakened PM May still hoping to push her Brexit deal through
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will address her Conservative lawmakers on Wednesday, possibly to set out a timetable for her departure in a last throw of the dice to win support for her twice-rejected Brexit deal in parliament.

Headline: UK lawmakers to vote on eight Brexit proposals
Description: British lawmakers will be able to vote on eight alternative Brexit options on Wednesday in a bid to find a way forward which could break the deadlock in parliament, the Speaker of the House of Commons said.

Headline: UK government should follow parliament's wishes on Brexit options - lawmaker Letwin
Description: Britain's government should pursue any alternative Brexit path that gains a majority in parliament and if it does not, parliament will seek to force it to do so, the Conservative lawmaker leading the process said on Wednesday.

Headline: Parliament taking control of Brexit is worrying precedent - minister
Description: Andrea Leadsom, who is in charge of the British government’s business in parliament, said on Wednesday the government would oppose the business motion allowing lawmakers to take control of the Brexit process, calling it a worrying precedent.

Headline: Tusk urges European Parliament to consider long Brexit delay
Description: The head of the European Council Donald Tusk urged the European Parliament on Wednesday to be open to a long Brexit extension and not to ignore the "increasing majority" of British people who wanted to remain in the European Union.

Headline: Northern Ireland must be treated differently after No Deal Brexit - Irish PM
Description: Northern Ireland must be treated differently from the rest of the United Kingdom immediately after a no-deal Brexit if a hard border on the island of Ireland is to be avoided, Ireland's Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Wednesday.

Headline: Labour will back customs union, new referendum as Brexit options - spokesman
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party will back Brexit proposals including keeping the country in the European Union's customs union and a new referendum when lawmakers vote alternatives to Prime Minister Theresa May's divorce deal on Wednesday.

Headline: Conservative lawmakers allowed 'free vote' on Brexit options - UK lawmakers
Description: Conservative lawmakers will be able to vote with their consciences, a so-called free vote, when considering alternative Brexit options later on Wednesday, two of them said.

Headline: May: I can deliver Brexit if MPs back my deal this week
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told lawmakers on Wednesday that she could fulfill her pledge to take Britain out of the European Union if they backed her divorce deal this week.

Headline: Labour will back Brexit options which prevent bad deal and 'no deal' - spokesman
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party will support Brexit proposals which keep options on the table to prevent a bad Conservative exit deal or a 'no deal', the party's spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Brexit: DUP says it will vote for Malthouse plan

Headline: "Dozens" of Conservatives still opposed to PM May's deal - UK lawmaker

Headline: DUP MEP Dodds says party won't accept May's Brexit deal
Description: The Democratic Unionist Party will not accept British Prime Minister Theresa May's proposed Brexit deal as it would endanger the integrity of the United Kingdom, the party's only member of the European Parliament said on Wednesday.

Headline: Brexit campaign chief: We would win another referendum by more
Description: The chief of the 2016 "Vote Leave" Brexit campaign said on Wednesday that opponents of European Union membership should start rebuilding the network and that they would win by a bigger margin if there was another referendum.

Headline: DUP says its Brexit position has not changed
Description: The Democratic Unionist Party's (DUP) position on Brexit remains unchanged, a spokesman for the Northern Irish party which props up Prime Minister Theresa May's government said on Wednesday.

Headline: Good Friday agreement will apply in all Brexit scenarios - EU's Barnier
Description: The Good Friday agreement to bring peace to Northern Ireland will continue to apply in all Brexit scenarios, the European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Wednesday.

Headline: Brexiteer Rees-Mogg says to back PM May's Brexit deal if DUP do

Headline: May might not announce resignation until MPs back Brexit deal - FT

Headline: UK parliament's indicative votes may not produce a deliverable result - minister
Description: Andrea Leadsom, who is in charge of the British government's business in parliament, has warned that lawmakers' plans to wrest control of the Brexit process on Wednesday may produce a result that the government cannot negotiate.

Headline: UK Conservative MP Letwin says will back PM May's deal
Description: British Conservative Party lawmaker Oliver Letwin, the architect of a series of votes on alternatives to Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plan, said on Wednesday he would continue to vote for her deal.

Headline: Brexit turmoil hits UK firms' hiring plans - REC
Description: British companies have scaled back sharply their hiring and investment plans amid the growing turmoil around Britain's exit from the European Union, a survey showed on Wednesday.

Headline: Labour pushes Brexit plan for close economic relationship with EU

Headline: Hardline Brexiteer Boris Johnson edging towards May's deal - Telegraph
Description: Former British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, one of the fiercest opponents of Theresa May's Brexit plan, is now edging towards backing her deal, Telegraph deputy political editor Steven Swinford said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK lawmaker Boles proposes common market 2.0 motion on Brexit - The Telegraph
Description: British Conservative lawmaker Nick Boles is proposing a common market 2.0 motion as a Brexit option to be voted on as part of a series of indicative votes to be held in parliament on Wednesday, according to a reporter at The Telegraph newspaper.

Headline: UK lawmaker proposes new UK-EU customs union as Brexit option
Description: A British lawmaker has proposed a motion with other parliamentarians to compel the government to negotiate a new UK-EU customs union after Brexit as part of a series of indicative votes due to be held on Wednesday.

Description: Pro-Brexit Conservative lawmakers have written to Prime Minister Theresa May to raise "serious legal doubts" over her decision to delay Britain's departure from the European Union, calling on her to explain the government's actions.

Headline: DUP says Brexit position unchanged after report it favours delay
Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party's (DUP) position on Brexit remains unchanged, a spokesman for the party propping up Prime Minister Theresa May's government said on Tuesday in response to a report that it favours a long delay.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP prefer long delay to May's Brexit deal - Sky News
Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which currently props up Prime Minister Theresa May's government, would prefer a long delay and change of leader to May's Brexit deal, Sky News reported on Tuesday.

Headline: PM May will engage constructively with parliament on Brexit options votes - spokesman
Description: British ministers had a long discussion on Tuesday about a vote by lawmakers late on Monday to seize control of the Brexit process and Prime Minister Theresa May will engage constructively with the process, her spokesman said.

Headline: EU watchdog sees no imminent banking risks from no-deal Brexit
Description: Euro zone banks face no imminent risks from a no-deal Brexit, the head of the European Union agency responsible for handling failing lenders said on Tuesday.

Headline: May expected to set resignation date on Wednesday - Sun newspaper
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is expected to set a date for her resignation when she addresses Conservative lawmakers on Wednesday afternoon, the Sun's political editor said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britons backing away from Brexit, but no safe bets - pollster

Description: National Grid, which runs Britain's energy systems, said on Tuesday that electricity and gas flows from continental Europe would continue as normal even under a no-deal Brexit as it has made preparations for all scenarios.

Headline: UK House of Commons leader Leadsom to make statement to parliament on Tuesday - office
Description: Andrea Leadsom, who is in charge of the British government's business in parliament, will make a statement to lawmakers on Tuesday, her office said on Twitter.

Headline: Head of UK Conservative eurosceptics: it's May's deal or no Brexit
Description: The leader of a faction in British Prime Minister Theresa May’s Conservative Party demanding a clean break from the European Union said there was a clear choice now facing lawmakers: back the government's divorce deal or risk no Brexit at all.

Headline: MPs vote to seize control of Brexit for a day

Headline: May would take lawmakers' Brexit proposals to Brussels - former minister

Headline: UK lawmakers who want no-deal Brexit must now back May: minister

Headline: Goldman Sachs keeps Brexit bets unchanged after UK parliament takes control

Headline: Shakespeare's birthplace mirrors a scepter'd isle riven by Brexit discontent

Headline: Brexit in numbers: How did parliament vote on Monday?
Description: British lawmakers on Monday used a vote on the government's next steps on Brexit to wrest control of the process so that they can then try to find a majority for an alternative that would break the parliamentary deadlock.

Headline: Britain calls for 'realism' on Brexit after parliament grabs control
Description: The British government on Monday called for realism after parliament grabbed control of Brexit.

Headline: May indicated she could resign as price for passing Brexit deal - The Sun
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May indicated to some Brexit-supporting lawmakers on Sunday that she would consider resigning in exchange for parliament backing her Brexit deal, The Sun newspaper reported.

Headline: Sterling rises after UK lawmakers vote to take control of Brexit process for a day
Description: Sterling rose at the start of the Asian trading session after British lawmakers voted to wrest control of the Brexit process from Prime Minister Theresa May's government for a day.

Headline: Junior foreign minister Burt resigns over Brexit
Description: British junior foreign minister Alistair Burt has resigned to vote against the government for a proposal to give parliament control over the Brexit process, Press Association reported.

Headline: UK lawmakers vote to take control of Brexit process
Description: British lawmakers on Monday voted to wrest control of the Brexit process to try to find a majority for an alternative way forward that would break the parliamentary deadlock.

Headline: Man jailed for cracking egg on head of opposition leader Corbyn

Headline: Parliament faces choice on who controls business - Brexit minister

Headline: Pro-Brexit ERG lawmakers to vote against all amendments on Monday - lawmaker
Description: The pro-Brexit European Research Group of Conservative lawmakers plans to vote against all proposed changes to Prime Minister Theresa May's next steps on Brexit on Monday, a Conservative lawmaker said.

Headline: Parliament's bid to control Brexit process is not constitutional revolution - lawmaker

Headline: UK government plans to give lawmakers a say on Brexit way forward this week - minister
Description: The British government will provide time for parliament to debate the way forward on Brexit later this week if an attempt by lawmakers to wrest control of the process does not pass on Monday, Cabinet Office minister David Lidington said.

Headline: Brexit up in the air as May pushes divorce deal for third time
Description: (Corrects this March 23 story to show the petition is to revoke Article 50, not for another vote.)

Headline: Brexit: What will happen in the British parliament on Monday?
Description: British lawmakers will on Monday seek to use a vote on the government's next steps on Brexit to wrest control of the process so that they can then try to find a majority for an alternative that would break the parliamentary deadlock.

Headline: Brexit: What will happen in the British parliament on Monday?
Description: British lawmakers will on Monday seek to use a vote on the government's next steps on Brexit to wrest control of the process so that they can then try to find a majority for an alternative that would break the parliamentary deadlock.

Headline: Parliament to vote on three proposed changes to PM May's next steps on Brexit
Description: British lawmakers will on Monday have the opportunity to vote on up to three proposed changes to Prime Minister Theresa May's next steps on Brexit, the Speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow, said.

Headline: Piling pressure on May, EU executive says no-deal Brexit plans complete
Description: EU officials said on Monday they had completed their plans for what they saw as an increasingly likely no-deal Brexit, piling pressure on British Prime Minister Theresa May as she battled to persuade her own lawmakers to back a divorce agreement.

Headline: Asked if she will lead next Brexit talks, May says she is doing the job
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday she was getting on with the job of delivering Brexit when asked if she would be leading the next phase of talks with the European Union.

Headline: UK leaving the EU without a Brexit deal would be difficult - PM May's spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May would find it difficult to take Britain out of the European Union without a Brexit divorce deal after parliament expressed a clear view that it is opposed to this outcome, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: May says parliament will debate formal delay to Brexit date on Wednesday
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday that parliament would debate secondary legislation on Wednesday to formally change the date of Brexit in British law.

Headline: May says she still hopes to bring her Brexit deal back to Parliament
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday she still hoped to submit her twice-defeated Brexit deal to another vote by lawmakers.

Headline: May's Brexit approach is "national embarrassment"- Labour leader
Description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, said on Monday that Prime Minister Theresa May's approach to Brexit had become "a national embarrassment" that risked Britain leaving the European Union without an agreement.

Headline: Not enough support yet for third Brexit vote, says May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said there was not yet enough support for her to put her Brexit deal to a vote in parliament for a third time, but she would continue with talks with lawmakers to try to get their backing.

Headline: JPMorgan asks 300 staff to move if no Brexit deal - source
Description: JPMorgan is asking around 300 staff in its London office to sign new contracts that will require them to move to one of the bank's other hubs in the European Union if there is a no-deal Brexit, according to a person familiar with the matter.

Headline: Corbyn told PM May: no basis for third vote on Brexit deal
Description: Britain's opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday there was no basis for bringing her twice-defeated Brexit deal back to parliament for a third vote, a party spokesman said.

Headline: Factbox: EU preparations for no-deal Brexit
Description: European Union officials said on Monday it was increasingly likely Britain would leave the bloc without a divorce deal after April 12 and the EU had completed contingency preparations for such a scenario.

Headline: DUP leader told May nothing has changed on Brexit stance - spokesman
Description: The leader of the Northern Irish party propping up Theresa May's government told the British prime minister on Monday that their opposition to her Brexit divorce deal had not changed, a spokesman for the party said.

Headline: UK lawmakers look set to win vote to take control of Brexit process: source
Description: British lawmakers are likely to win a vote on Monday to wrestle control of the Brexit process from the government by trying to find a majority for an alternative way forward to break the parliamentary deadlock, a government source said.

Headline: May will only hold new Brexit vote if there's a chance of success - spokesman
Description: Britain's government will only hold another so-called meaningful vote on Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal if it has a chance of getting the support of parliament on a third attempt, her spokesman said.

Headline: No shift in DUP stance against May's Brexit plan - BBC
Description: The leader of the Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party, Arlene Foster, showed no change in her opposition to Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal in a telephone call with May on Monday, the BBC's political editor Laura Kuenssberg said.

Headline: UK PM May could put her Brexit deal to a vote in parliament on Tuesday - ITV reporter
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May could put her twice-defeated Brexit divorce deal to a vote in parliament on Tuesday, ITV's political correspondent said, though he later said no final decision had yet been taken on the timing.

Headline: After London march, EU still assumes UK will leave - Commission
Description: The European Commission is working on the assumption that Britain will leave the EU unless the UK government tells it otherwise, the European Commision said on Monday after hundreds of thousands of people marched in London on Saturday to demand a new referendum.

Headline: Brexit is burden for German industry - Ifo economist
Description: Britain's expected departure from the European Union is a burden for German industry in particular, an economist at the Ifo institute said on Monday, adding that the global economy was not providing any support.

Headline: May should not resign over Brexit - pensions minister
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May should not resign in the face of intensified criticism from her own Conservative Party over her handling of Brexit, work and pensions minister Amber Rudd said on Monday.

Headline: UK might not leave EU at all if May's deal fails - Fox
Description: British trade minister Liam Fox said on Monday that Britain might not leave the European Union if Prime Minister Theresa May's deal is not approved by parliament, triggering a democratic and constitutional crisis.

Headline: UK ministers meet to discuss parliament's bid for Brexit control - source
Description: British ministers will discuss how to address parliament's attempts to take control of Britain's departure from the European Union at 0900 GMT on Monday before a meeting of Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet team, a government source said.

Headline: PM May told Brexiteers she'll quit if they vote for her deal - ITV
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told Brexit-supporting lawmakers on Sunday that she would quit if they voted for her twice-defeated European Union divorce deal, ITV news said.

Headline: May has lost confidence of cabinet and party - lawmaker
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has lost the confidence of her senior ministers, lawmakers and party members, and should step down, said Andrew Bridgen, a Conservative lawmaker who supports a hard Brexit.

Headline: Britain can still avoid no-deal Brexit, says EU Commissioner Moscovici
Description: EU Economic Affairs and Tax Commissioner Pierre Moscovici said on Monday he believed Britain would not leave the European Union without a withdrawal agreement.

Headline: May must go once her Brexit deal clears parliament: lawmaker
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May should be given time to get her Brexit deal through parliament before making way for someone else to lead the next phase of negotiations with the European Union, a eurosceptic lawmaker from her Conservative Party said.

Headline: Markets seem to underestimate threat of Brexit - ECB's Rehn
Description: The risk of Britain leaving the European Union without a deal is the biggest risk facing the slowing euro zone economy in the short term, Finnish central bank chief Olli Rehn told Germany's Die Welt newspaper in remarks published on Monday.

Headline: 'Time's up, Theresa' Sun newspaper says of British PM May
Description: Rupert Murdoch's The Sun newspaper said in a front page editorial that Prime Minister Theresa May must on Monday announce she will stand down as soon as her Brexit deal is approved and the United Kingdom has left the European Union.

Headline: PM May to offer indicative votes on Brexit options - Telegraph reporter
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is considering offering lawmakers so called indicative votes to find a way to break the Brexit deadlock, The Daily Telegraph's deputy political editor said.

Headline: PM May was told - set out her exit date to get Brexit deal approved
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May was told at a meeting on Sunday with Brexit-supporting rebel lawmakers that she must set out a timetable to leave office if she wants to get her Brexit deal ratified, a Buzzfeed reporter said.

Headline: PM May met rebel lawmakers to discuss her Brexit deal
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May met senior colleagues and Brexit-supporting rebel lawmakers on Sunday at her country residence to discuss her strategy and whether there is sufficient support to put her deal to another vote this week.

Headline: Uri Geller urges mass-telepathy against Brexit
Description: Spoon-bending psychic Uri Geller wants to bend British Prime Minister Theresa May's will against Brexit using mass-telepathy.

Headline: UK could face risk of election if parliament takes control of Brexit - Barclay
Description: A British election could be the consequence of parliament seizing control of the Brexit process this week if lawmakers back proposals contrary to the pledges the government was elected on, Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain must resolve Brexit but changing PM May wouldn't help, Hammond says
Description: Britain must find a way to leave the European Union in an orderly fashion rather than trying to oust Prime Minister Theresa May, finance minister Philip Hammond said on Sunday.

Headline: UK minister Gove backs PM May, saying it is not the time to change captain
Description: Britain's Environment Secretary Michael Gove said on Sunday Prime Minister Theresa May "absolutely" had his support, adding that it was a time for "cool heads" to focus on getting her  twice-rejected Brexit agreement approved by lawmakers.

Headline: Theresa May's de facto deputy says - I don't think I want to be PM
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's de-facto deputy said on Sunday he did not think he had any wish to take her job.

Headline: Can't get the staff - Scenic Highlands at eye of Scotland's Brexit storm
Description: Glen Mhor Hotel, a picturesque base for tourists hunting Scotland's Loch Ness monster, is struggling to find staff for the summer season as workers from the European Union snub Brexit Britain.

Headline: PM May facing plot from minister to oust her - Sunday Times reporter
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is facing a full-blown cabinet plot to remove her and 11 cabinet ministers have said they want her to resign, The Sunday Times's political editor said.

Headline: Hundreds of thousands march in London to demand new Brexit referendum
Description: Hundreds of thousands of people opposed to Britain's withdrawal from the European Union marched through central London on Saturday to demand a new referendum as the deepening Brexit crisis risked sinking Prime Minister Theresa May's premiership.

Headline: Ireland promises 'substantial' aid to farmers in no-deal Brexit
Description: Ireland's agriculture minister Michael Creed on Saturday promised farmers a "substantial" aid package if they suffer losses as a result of new UK tariffs under a no-deal Brexit.

Headline: Wheat fields and underpants: Brexit satire lampoons British leaders on huge march
Description: Thousands of anti-Brexit protesters on Saturday displayed a sometimes bizarre array of placards to lampoon British leaders and Brexit with references to everything from fields of wheat to ornithology.

Headline: Factbox: What happens next on Brexit?
Description: European Union leaders have given Prime Minister Theresa May a two week reprieve before Britain could leave the bloc without an exit deal if she fails to win parliament's backing for her agreement with Brussels.

Headline: Returning to London, May faces mammoth task to change minds on Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday began the mammoth struggle of persuading a deeply divided parliament to back her Brexit deal after an EU summit granted her more time but little to help change minds at home.

Headline: May hints she might not bring Brexit deal back for third parliament vote next week
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May hinted on Friday that she might not bring her European Union withdrawal deal back to parliament for a third time next week if there was not enough support for it to be passed.

Headline: Echoing de Gaulle, Macron sees Brexit Britain as poor fit for Europe
Description: France's wartime hero Charles de Gaulle twice vetoed Britain's attempts to join the European Economic Community in the 1960s, convinced the country was a poor fit for Europe.

Headline: UK's Clark says government will allow lawmakers indicative Brexit votes
Description: Britain's business minister Greg Clark said on Friday that the government would allow parliament to hold votes to indicate what Brexit plans might be able to command the support of a majority of lawmakers.

Headline: EU summit an "inexcusable" failure for UK PM, DUP says
Description: Nothing has changed as far as the Brexit divorce deal British Prime Minister Theresa May is seeking to convince lawmakers to back, the deputy leader of the Northern Irish party propping up her government said on Friday.

Headline: UK lawmakers might vote on Brexit alternatives on Weds - Corbyn
Description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party said votes on alternative Brexit plans to Prime Minister Theresa May's deal could be held in parliament on Wednesday, and there was support for other proposals.

Headline: French President Macron says Europe must not remain hostage to Brexit
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron said Europe must not remain a hostage to the ongoing Brexit process, as British Prime Minister Theresa May struggles to persuade a deeply divided parliament to back her Brexit deal after an EU summit granted her more time.

Headline: France talks tough on no-deal Brexit deadline, at odds with others
Description: France said on Friday that Britain would crash out of the European Union on April 12 if it fails to ratify the Brexit withdrawal agreement and present a new plan, putting it at odds with other member states which adopted a softer stance.

Headline: Brexit fatigue, Ireland's Varadkar says hopes Brexit deal will pass UK parliament
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Friday he hoped British Prime Minister Theresa May will get her deal to leave the European Union through parliament, adding that both sides have Brexit fatigue.

Headline: May determined to deliver Brexit deal, no date yet for new vote - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is determined to deliver on her Brexit deal and end uncertainty, her spokesman said on Friday, although he could not confirm when lawmakers would be given a vote to approve that agreement.

Headline: If Britain rejects deal again, hard Brexit looms closer - Austria's Kurz
Description: Austria's Chancellor Sebastian Kurz said on Friday he hoped the withdrawal agreement negotiated between Britain and the remaining European Union states would now pass the British parliament after EU leaders granted Britain extra time.

Headline: The Brexit ending: deal, no deal, or no divorce?
Description: Just days before the United Kingdom was due to leave the European Union, the March 29 cliff edge was moved by two weeks to April 12 but it is still uncertain how, when or if Brexit will happen.

Headline: Franklin Templeton's Zahn says 30 percent probability of no-deal Brexit, may rise further
Description: There is a 30 percent chance of Britain crashing out of the European Union without a divorce deal in place, Franklin Templeton's head of European fixed income, David Zahn, said on Friday.

Headline: Best Brexit outcome would be remain vote in a new referendum - Luxembourg PM
Description: Luxembourg Prime Minister Xavier Bettel put the chances of Britain's parliament passing the withdrawal deal at 50-50 and said the best possible Brexit outcome would be a new referendum and a vote to stay in the European Union.

Headline: May gets two-week Brexit reprieve from impatient EU
Description: European Union leaders have given Prime Minister Theresa May two weeks' reprieve, until April 12, before Britain could lurch out of the EU if she fails to persuade MPs to back the withdrawal treaty she concluded with Brussels.

Headline: Brexit agreement is the right one - Belgium's Michel
Description: Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel said the deal reached by European leaders in the early hours of Friday morning to grant Britain a conditional Brexit delay was the right one and gave clarity.

Headline: Brexit deal 'very, very unlikely' to pass - Conservative eurosceptic
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is "very, very unlikely" to win support in parliament for the Brexit divorce deal she agreed with the European Union, a eurosceptic member of her minority government said on Friday.

Headline: Brexit delay gives economy a moment to breathe, nothing more - Germany's DIHK
Description: The reprieve the European Union had given Britain for the deadline of its departure from the EU gives the economy a moment to breathe, but nothing more, the head of Germany's chambers of commerce DIHK said on Friday.

Headline: Goldman Sachs raises chances of no-deal Brexit after PM's late reprieve
Description: Goldman Sachs on Friday lowered its expectations of UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal getting ratified, and hiked its estimate of the chances of a "no-deal" exit from the European Union.

Headline: Five percent? EU leaders doubt May's Brexit vote chances
Description: After British Prime Minister Theresa May reassured them she could win a crunch vote in parliament next week to ensure an orderly Brexit, EU leaders were left even more doubtful of her chances.

Headline: End the Brexit ambiguity, Macron tells Britain
Description: The European Union has made clear its options for delaying Brexit and now it is time for Britain to lift all ambiguities surrounding its position, French President Emmanuel Macron said on Friday.

Headline: May welcomes Brexit delay, says parliament now has clear choice
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday welcomed the European Union's decision to delay Brexit, saying that MPs in the British parliament now had clear choices about what to do next.

Headline: EU's Tusk says all Brexit options still open until April 12
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk said on Thursday all Brexit options were still open for Britain until April 12 after a summit of EU leaders agreed on Prime Minister Theresa May's request to delay the leave date from March 29.

Headline: Text of EU summit agreement on Brexit
Description: 1. The European Council takes note of the letter of Prime Minister Theresa May of 20 March 2019.

Headline: EU summit talks on Brexit finished, official says
Description: Thursday's European Union summit talks on Brexit have ended, an official said.

Headline: EU to offer Brexit delay, length depends on UK parliament - draft
Description: The European Union will grant Britain an extension to its Brexit negotiating period, but the length of the delay will depend on whether Prime Minister Theresa May is able to win a vote in parliament on an exit agreement next week, draft summit conclusions said.

Headline: EU looks at two-stage approach to Brexit delay - diplomats
Description: European Union leaders were considering an offer of a two-stage Brexit delay on Thursday, depending on whether Prime Minister Theresa May gets her divorce deal approved by the British parliament next week, diplomatic sources said.

Headline: EU considers options for Brexit delay - May 7, year-end or open-ended, diplomats say
Description: European Union leaders were considering different options on delaying Brexit on Thursday, possibly until May 7, the end of the year or even leaving the date open for now, diplomatic sources said.

Headline: Stop Brexit - A million people sign UK petition to stay in EU
Description: More than one million people have rushed to sign a petition on the British parliament's website calling for the government to revoke its divorce notice to the European Union and remain in the bloc.

Headline: EU offers Brexit delay until May 22 - draft statement
Description: The European Union will agree to hand Britain a Brexit delay until May 22 if its parliament approves the divorce agreement next week, according to draft conclusions considered by the other 27 national leaders on Thursday.

Headline: May to give news conference in Brussels later - PM's office
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will hold a news conference in Brussels later on Thursday, her office said, without giving a specific time.

Headline: UK watchdog leaves options open after Brexit trading spat with EU
Description: British and European Union market regulators should look beyond public sparring this week over share trading to the "bigger picture" of future relations after Brexit, a senior British regulator said on Thursday.

Headline: Deutsche Bank hikes no-deal Brexit probability
Description: Deutsche Bank on Thursday hiked its expectation of a no-deal Brexit to 20 percent - the highest level ever - from 10 percent as the third attempt to get UK parliamentary approval for the nation's exit from the European Union looms.

Headline: May's "reckless" Brexit message angers the lawmakers she needs to win over
Description: If British Prime Minister Theresa May hoped a televised address late on Wednesday would help persuade wavering lawmakers to support her Brexit deal, it appears to have backfired, instead alienating the very people she needs to win over.

Headline: Britain headed towards no-deal if parliament votes down Brexit deal: Macron
Description: Britain is headed towards a no-deal Brexit scenario if its parliament votes against Prime Minister Theresa May's withdrawal agreement for a third time next week, French President Emmanuel Macron said on Thursday.

Headline: We'll fight for a Brexit deal, but prepare for failure - Merkel
Description: The European Union must do everything possible to ensure that Britain leaves the bloc in an orderly fashion, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said ahead of a European Council summit that is set to be dominated by Brexit.

Headline: May's Brexit deal now less likely, election more likely - JP Morgan
Description: JP Morgan said it no longer thought the single most likely outcome for Brexit would be Prime Minister Theresa May getting approval in parliament for her deal in the first half of 2019, and a new national election was now more likely.

Headline: May could back no-deal if she loses third Brexit vote - Sky citing cabinet source
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May could back leaving the European Union without a deal over a longer delay if she loses a third parliamentary vote on her Brexit plan next week, a cabinet source has told Sky News.

Headline: Top bankers back London as financial hub whatever Brexit outcome
Description: London will be central to global financial markets whatever shape Britain's exit deal from the European Union (EU) takes, senior players in British banking said on Thursday.

Headline: No-deal Brexit would hurt EU significantly - Barclays
Description: A no-deal Brexit would significantly harm the European Union and a deal on financial services between Britain and the EU is likely whatever form Brexit takes, Barclays Chairman John McFarlane said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain extends Northern Ireland talks, but no resolution seen
Description: Britain sought to extend by five months the period for allowing a new devolved government to be formed in Northern Ireland, but parties in the province saw little hope a two-year deadlock would be broken.

Headline: Corbyn says he will try to renegotiate Brexit deal
Description: British Labour opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said after meeting the EU's Brexit negotiator that he will push ahead with Brexit and seek to renegotiate the terms of the divorce deal.

Headline: May says short Brexit delay will give Britain time to make final choice
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday a short delay to Britain's departure from the European Union would give parliament time to make a final choice on Brexit, hours before she will make her case with EU leaders for an extension.

Headline: Merkel lends support to Tusk's offer of short Brexit delay
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed readiness on Thursday to back a short extension to Britain's planned exit from the European Union, suggesting that the June 30 date requested by Prime Minister Theresa May was problematic.

Headline: Cut Britain some slack, but no rolling extension says Ireland's Varadkar
